I'm glad someone created this thread. I wanted to let you guys know that I am so happy you exist. Honestly. I know you guys get a lot of flak here on the forums and, personally, I don't understand it. You listen to us when we make suggestions and politely correct us when we make a mistake. That is very honorable, in my opinion.

And the game. Good gravy, the game! I have spent days of my life playing this game and I only got it a month ago! My sleep schedule has gone completely awry and I couldn't be happier! And I am sure .17 and .18 and what ever follows will be awesome! Keep up the good work and for heaven's sake, take all the time you need!

I'd like to share an observation with You guys.

When I first bought KSP it had the scent of novelty. I played it every free moment of my life until next update. I THINK it was .11

Then when the 'shiny new toy' stopped being new (still shiny thou), I've played maybe every 4-5 days. Just for fun, to relax.

And here's the observation: That ratio is growing. We are on .16 and there are hardly any days I don't play KSP.

Conclusion is simple. weter You guys are doing this on purpose or not, KSP is becoming MOAR addictive by the update.

And that's what I would like to thank You SQUAD. You've managed to cure my Minecraft addiction by replacing it with (clearly better) KSP addiction

So Thank YOU! And Happy New Easter!

Thank you for creating such a unique, awesome, and ever-improving game. I have never seen anything like it in my whole life, and it's my all-time favorite. Seriously, you guys are amazing.

The game really evokes a bit of the wonder I had when I was a kid watching the space shuttles launch. Even better, my 7 year old daughter sat on my lap for a few hours watching me play KSP. We laughed at my rockets horrible yet hilarious failures. When we finally starting making our way in to space/orbit she was equally excited. We talked weight and fuel consumption, and the next steps in our quest to Mun. It's not often a game can foster this type of thing from a Dad and his kids...so seriously...thanks.

Not only is KSP fun, I really think this game could be used in schools and other educational environments with small(er) kids. If the Oregon Trail and Carmen Sandiego can, so can KSP.

I love this game. I was using Orbiter sim for a long time, and I still find it superior to KSP in some ways (the orbital physics is lot more accurate in it, and the feel of flying in the Solar system is great), but the easy and entertaining approach of KSP is something I really appreciate. The overall presentation is very nice, the controls are reasonably complex, yet easy to grasp. What I probably appreciate most is the map screen, which I find very intuitive, with its orbit displays and maneuver planning.

The choice of smaller solar system and a planet with the same gravity as Earth, but a lot smaller, with shorter orbits is I think excellent, as it greatly reduces the time requirements for missions, while keeping the principles realistic.

Building the ships, crashing them again and again and learning from mistakes, then finally reaching my next milestone (be it reaching orbit, or reaching the Mun) is really rewarding and entertaining.

Well done.

It has also inspired me to become an Engineer, and my eventual goal is to work at NASA or some other space flight agency, working to bring the things I've done in the game into real life!

Me too dude, only I want to end up any where in space development. See you out there.

Wish I had it when I was studying orbital mechanics during my university years. Helps me to visualize what all those equations and calculations for a Hohmann transfer mean. I look forward to further refinement of the aerodynamics as well as squashing out all the bugs.

Also, I am sorry to hear about the DLC and Expansions issue. I feel that Squad has proven to everyone that they are listening to their customers and this is a hallmark of a great customer-oriented company. Go Squad!

When I get a new game I am excited about it and play only that game. Eventually, the appeal starts to fade and I alternate that game with another one, and eventually exhaust the game's potential and set it aside. For most games that initial honeymoon period can last from a few days to 3 months or so. My previous record holder was Morrowind, which I played just about every day for 10 months, without taking a break to play other games. But as of today, I have been playing KSP and only KSP for 11 months. So that should tell you how much I like KSP.

If kerbal space program was an organic thing, i'd have babies with it.

Adult Swim already has NASA, so this is the next best thing. Seeing how I'm working for a degree in Astrophysics, (third year now) Kerbal Space Program is a great way to wind down my day of studies. Thanks, Squad.
